overview:
Dennis Adonis is a Guyanese-born Computer Software Engineer, Educational Author, Novelist, Musician, and intellectual.

He was the first author of an instructional book governing fundamentals and guidelines for first-time users of the Windows 8 Operating system, from Microsoft.

In his capacity as a computer software engineer, he has penned five books aligned to computer science teachings, namely; -

1 - Mastering Information Technology v.1 2 - An Introduction to Windows 8 3 - Internet Communications security guidebook 4 - An Introduction to computers for children (age 3 to 5) 5 - Computer self-training for Children (ages 6 to 9)

He has also penned several other novels of varying genres including; -

1 - The Pastor’s Wife (a Romance work) 2 - Child of a Slave (An African historical fiction) 3 - Boyhood Days (a Caribbean narrative and folklore comprising five books).

As a musician, he has been highly credited for his innovations and contribution to the advancement of copyright administration in the Caribbean, notably Barbados, St. Vincent and the Grenadines, and to a lesser extent, the Bahamas.

He has also recorded a series of songs varying genres on several notable music compilations spanning nearly 15 years, and which includes over a dozen singles recorded with various regional studios including Kross Kolor Records, VP Music and Green Sleeves in the United Kingdom.

Adopting the musical stage name of Aevvio, he is currently signed to the TuneCore label which has allowed for a produce-then-pay deal with online music distributors Apple iTunes, MySpace Music and Zune.

Based in London, United Kingdom, Adonis has established his own recording facility in Dublin, Ireland and another one in the upscale Inch Marlow community in Barbados, where he records music of genres that spills over into the world of RnB and new age.

Unlike most Caribbean musicians, Adonis is a University educated Software Engineer, but also holds extensive experience in copyright administration, artiste management, and song writing.

He is also known to promote over two dozen international music concerts through his management company, SoundProof Music. But has been shadowed by the flopping of two entertainment events (a Wrestling promotion and a reggae concert) that fell through after major sponsors in Guyana pulled out. While Adonis is highly respected and commands a fair commercial reputation Caribbean-wide, two of his failed business ventures in Guyana has thrown him into disrepute in his homeland.
